author: CBD
title: First day in the office but 'pay gap' on the agenda for Ten boss Paul Anderson
text:
Illustration: John Shakespeare.
It wasn't an easy first day in the office for Ten's new boss, Paul Anderson , who was anointed after Monday's very abrupt CEO switcheroo with Hamish McLennan .
Less than 24 hours into his new role, Anderson was shepherded into the Network Ten Studio at its Pyrmont HQ, fronting a chief executive forum on "Tackling the gender pay gap" as a last-minute substitute for McLennan, who departed with immediate effect.
Thanks Hamish.
The Workplace Gender Equality Agency and the NSW Equal Employment Opportunity Practitioners Association (NEEOPA) hosted a couch-load of CEOs who have committed to standing up for pay equity in their own organisations.
Advertisement Aside from Anderson, this included Mirvac's Susan Lloyd-Hurwtiz , and Michael Greene from law firm Henry Davis York.
Anderson's short tenure means Ten talent Natarsha Belling did not have much to work with in terms of grilling the new boss on what he has done during his brief tenure to ensure The Project's Carrie Bickmore is paid as much as Waleed Aly .
Anderson proved to be safe at the crease despite copping a few bouncers, including queries about a former network boss's notorious use of the word "boning" as a euphemism for removing female talent: "That's not a term that we would use here," Anderson told the audience.
And the blokey culture in network television? "That's not the case at Ten, I think it's probably the exact opposite."
Anderson has even been known to take his kids to school in the morning.
The audience was told how making the workplace more female-friendly improves staff turnover. Maybe Ten can apply this to its CEO suite, which has had five occupants in the past five years; perhaps it's time for a woman, watch this space, at this rate we shouldn't have to wait long.
Pay gap At least Anderson could sympathise with his female colleagues on the "pay gap" issue.
He has started as the new Ten boss on a $1.25 million base pay packet, which means he is well short of 'pay parity" with his rock-star predecessor. McLennan was on a base salary closer to the $2 million mark.
We are sure McLennan was able to explain the reason for this particular "pay gap" given he would have been on the other side of the negotiating table as executive chairman.
God almighty The age of the God CEO might be over, but it does not mean a demigod like Wesfarmers boss Richard Goyder couldn't attract a decent crowd to his John Monash Oration on the above subject on Tuesday night.
The topic obviously did not apply to the John Monash Foundation's patron-in-chief, our GeeGee Sir Peter Cosgrove , who was busy elsewhere.
Commonwealth Bank boss Ian Narev might have had a bit more sympathy for the argument that "the age when chief executive officers were regarded as all-powerful, God-like figures is well and truly over".
But as your columnist's deadline approached, Narev was only a tentative "yes" to attend the oration despite the fact it was being held at the bank's Sydney HQ, and was being hosted by one of his direct reports, Kelly Bayer Rosmarin .
Fairfax's departing chairman, Roger Corbett , was due to attend â€“ obviously to tell Goyder how much better it was in his day as a deity when Woolies was lording it all over Wesfarmers' grocery shop, Coles.
Former Telstra boss David Thodey was also on the guest list, along with style maven and former SBS chair Carla Zampatti .
Friendly faces in the audience for Goyder included Wesfarmers board member Diane Smith-Gander , who champions the rights of women in the executive suite when she isn't chairing Transfield Services.
The group is copping a drubbing from a Senate inquiry at the moment over its running of the detention facilities at Manus Island and Nauru. According to recent testimony, female asylum seekers were denied easy access to sanitary pads for "security reasons".
Monash man Former deputy PM Tim Fischer was always going to be a reliable fixture at the Monash oration.
He recently emerged as Monash's latest champion with his publishing debut: Maestro John Monash: Australia's Greatest Citizen General .
Fisher sought to right some of the wrongs meted out against a man he regards as one of our nation's greats.
Despite his heroic role during World War I, Monash fell out of favour with various parties, according to Fisher.
This includes Australia's war correspondent C.E.W. Bean and the influential reporter Keith Murdoch .
Keith's subsequent fame as a press baron has been outshone by his son, Rupert Murdoch .
